contentList.content: The Dread Overlord

You're a cultist fighting under the banner of the Dread Overlord, a monstrous dracolich necromancer who seeks to spread His maleficence and terror over all lands. In return for your service, boundless power over death itself and the promise of eternal life await. Command the very souls of the dead and raise powerful Greater Undead in His profane name!
Your patron is the Dread Overlord, a monstrous dracolich necromancer who seeks to spread His maleficence and terror over all lands.
Skeletal Giant
Skeletal Warlock
Siael's Scythe of the Deathmage
Massive Ancient Scythe
Ancient Bone Staff
This massive imposing scythe is covered with rust, a weapon of something dangerous and colossal.

An aged bone staff, weathered by time in ancient crypts. Its surface is etched with faded runes that pulse faintly in necromantic energies. A grinning skull crowns the top, impaled on a spine of a long-forgotten victim.

Forged by a macabre weaponsmith, this massive scythe's metallic surface is covered in dried blood. A weapon of the deathmages fighting under the banner of the Order of the Dracolich, it glows a sickly green hinting of the insidious necromancy that empowers it.
Bone Staff
Siael's Bone Staff of the Occultist

Crafted by a grim weaponsmith, this gruesome-looking quarterstaff was made from the spine and skull of a victim, a standard issue weapon of a Dread Cultist fighting under the banner of the Order of the Dracolich.
Skull Flail
A skull has been fashioned into the striking head of this gruesome-looking flail, a standard issue weapon of a Dread Cultist fighting under the banner of the Order of the Dracolich.
Bone Sickle
A sliver of bone fashioned into a sharp sickle, a standard issue weapon of a Dread Cultist fighting under the banner of the Order of the Dracolich.
Dread Cultist

As a cultist trained by the <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="DreadOverlord_LORE_OrderOfTheDracolich">Order of the Dracolich</LSTag>, you are <LSTag Tooltip="WeaponProficiency">Proficient</LSTag> in Flails, Maces, Scimitars, Sickles, and Shields. You may call upon the <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="DreadOverlord_LORE_DreadOverlord">Dread Overlord's</LSTag> power to ignite your weapon with His dark fire with the cantrip <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_DreadOverlord_NecroticBlade">Necrotic Armaments</LSTag> at-will.
Forbidden Lore

Your pact with the Dread Overlord has cursed you with profane knowledge. Add +1 to any roll made with either Arcana or History.

Fell lore has taught you how to curse enemies harmed by Necrotic damage from your cantrips, spells, and weapon attacks with Night of the Living Dead, dooming them to undeath. You also know how to Create Crawling Claws from the corpses of humanoids and beasts.
Invoker of Spirits: Soul Harvest

You may harvest souls of the dead and bind them in a soulshield for protection or invoke the spirits' wrath against your enemies. You can command the souls of the dead to surround you in a protective Shield of Souls, initially adding +[1] to your Armor Class until Long Rest.

You may bind additional spirits to your soulshield with Commit Corpse. Each Captured Soul provides an additional +[2] to Armor Class.

You may command the captured soul to do your bidding in combat. As long as you have a Captured Soul available, you may invoke the spirit to Spook your enemies, protect an ally through a ghostly Apparition, or will the vengeful Phantasm to strike your enemies.

Harvesting souls beyond the current capacity of your soulshield overcharges it deflecting all weapon and projectiles for a short time. It will also result in an Empowered Soulshield granting additional effects to your spirit invocations.
Invoker of Spirits: Improved Soul Harvest

You may harvest souls of the dead and bind them in an improved soulshield for protection or invoke the spirits' wrath against your enemies. You can command the souls of the dead to surround you in a protective Shield of Souls, initially adding +[1] to your Armor Class until Long Rest.

You may bind additional spirits to your soulshield from corpses with Commit Corpse or Reap the Dead. Each Captured Soul provides an additional +[2] to Armor Class.

Your command of the souls of the dead has grown in power: you may invoke the spirits with improved versions of Spook, Apparition, and Phantasm. You may also invoke the spirits to Haunt an enemy or enlist a Poltergeist to push enemies away.

Harvesting souls beyond the current capacity of your soulshield overcharges it deflecting all spell and weapon projectiles for a short time. It will also result in an Empowered Soulshield granting additional effects to your spirit invocations.
Invoker of Spirits: Greater Soul Harvest

You may harvest souls of the dead and bind them in a greater soulshield for protection or invoke the spirits' wrath against your enemies. You can command the souls of the dead to surround you in a protective Shield of Souls, initially adding +[1] to your Armor Class until Long Rest.

You may bind additional spirits to your soulshield from corpses with Commit Corpse or Reap the Dead, or rip the souls of nearly dead enemies with Reap the Dying. Each Captured Soul provides an additional +[2] to Armor Class.

Invoke the spirits with greater Spook, Apparition, Phantasm, Haunt, and Poltergeist.

Harvesting souls beyond the current capacity of your soulshield overcharges it deflecting all spell and weapon projectiles for a short time. It will also result in an Empowered Soulshield granting additional effects to your spirit invocations.
Souls of the Dead
You are surrounded by a swirling vortex of lost and phantom spirits screaming in terror as you bind them to your <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_DreadOverlord_Soulshield">soulshield</LSTag>.
Toggle off to silence the <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="DREADOVERLORD_SOULSHIELD_EFFECT">Screaming Spirits</LSTag>.
Pact of Eternal Life

Gain the power of life and death by imbuing yourself with the abilities of the undead - of vampires, wraiths, and banshees - through an unholy <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_DreadOverlord_ShroudDeAeternusVitae">Shroud of Eternal Life</LSTag>.
Dark Empathy

The dark tendrils emanating from your <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_DreadOverlord_ShroudDeAeternusVitae">Shroud de Aeternus Vitae</LSTag> are attuned to the life around you. You may activate this dark empathy to increase the vampiric shroud's range and share half of the vitality it drains with nearby allies. Once the effect ends, your shroud will take some time to refresh.
Hide Shroud
Retract the dark tendrils emanating from your vampiric shroud.
<LSTag Type="Image" Info="SoftWarning"/> Turns off visual effects while out of combat.
Summoner of the Damned
Summoner of the Damned: Create Undead
You know the spell <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_AnimateDead">Animate Dead</LSTag> which you may cast at-will.
You may now raise Ghouls and Flying Ghouls with the spell <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_AnimateDead">Animate Dead</LSTag> which you continue to cast at-will.
Summoner of the Damned: Skeletal Warlock
Summoner of the Damned: Ghouls and Flying Ghouls

You gain the power to create Greater Undead such as a Skeletal Warlock without expending a Warlock Spell Slot once per Long Rest.

You may summon each type of Greater Undead in addition to a minor undead from the spell Animate Dead.

Your power to command the Greater Undead grows. You can now raise a terrifying Skeletal Giant without expending a Warlock Spell Slot once per Long Rest.

You may summon each type of Greater Undead in addition to a minor undead from the spell Animate Dead.

Your power to command the <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="DreadOverlord_ImmuneToControlUndead">Greater Undead</LSTag> grows. You may command a nightmarish <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_DreadOverlord_SummonHungeringDarkness">Spectral Horror</LSTag> without expending a <LSTag Tooltip="WarlockSpellSlot">Warlock Spell Slot</LSTag> once per <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>. You also know the spell <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_CreateUndead">Create Undead</LSTag>, allowing you to raise a fearsome mummy at-will. This does not count towards spells gained from the Mystic Arcanum feature.
Greater Undead

This powerful <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="Undead">undead</LSTag> is <LSTag Tooltip="Immune">Immune</LSTag> from the effects of <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_ControlUndead">Control Undead</LSTag> and has <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="TurnResistance">Turn Undead</LSTag> and <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="MagicResistance">Magic</LSTag> <LSTag Tooltip="Resistant">resistances</LSTag>.
Fury of the Undead

This <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="DreadOverlord_ImmuneToControlUndead">Greater Undead</LSTag> strikes with phenomenal power! It knocks nearby creatures <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="PRONE">Prone</LSTag> every time it lands a <LSTag Tooltip="CriticalHit">Critical Hit</LSTag> or a killing blow.
Eternal Servitude

In return for its service after death, this <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="DreadOverlord_ImmuneToControlUndead">Greater Undead</LSTag> has access to Pact Magic from the necromancer's patron, allowing it to cast spells. It has two Level 2 <LSTag Tooltip="WarlockSpellSlot">Warlock Spell Slots</LSTag> which recharges after every <LSTag Tooltip="ShortRest">Short Rest</LSTag>.
Unholy Vigor: Resistance to Necrotic Damage
Your <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="DreadOverlord_UnholyVigor">Unholy Vigor</LSTag> makes you <LSTag Tooltip="Resistant">Resistant</LSTag> to Necrotic damage.
Unholy Vigor

You are Resistant to[1].

Imbuing your weapon with Necrotic Armaments fills you Unholy Vigor, making you Immune to[1] unless the damage dealt exceeds 10 hit points for a short time.
Necrotic Armaments

Ignite your weapon with the Undying Emperor's dark fire for a short time, dealing an additional [1]. Your imbued weapon cannot be disarmed by enemies. Flails, maces, scimitars, sickles, quarterstaves, and daggers wielded offhand are also ignited.
Shield of Souls

Summon lost souls from the grave and form them into a protective shield around you. Binding additional souls to your soulshield confer increased protection and unlocks the ability to invoke the spirits to do your bidding, whether for good or for malintent.

Gain +[1] to your Armor Class until Long Rest. Bind additional souls to your soulshield with Commit Corpse, which adds +[4] to your Armor Class per additional soul.

Harvesting souls beyond the current capacity of your soulshield overcharges it deflecting all spell and weapon projectiles for a short time. It will also result in an Empowered Soulshield granting additional effects to your spirit invocations.
<LSTag Type="Image" Info="SoftWarning"/> Wearing Light, Medium, or Heavy Armor in any slot restrict your ability to retain captured souls.
Commit Corpse

Perform a ritual to bind the soul of a slain being to your <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_DreadOverlord_Soulshield">Shield of Souls</LSTag>. Each <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="DREADOVERLORD_HARVESTED_SOUL">Captured Soul</LSTag> adds +[1] to your <LSTag Tooltip="ArmorClass">Armor Class</LSTag> until <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>.
Reap the Dead

Bind the souls of fallen enemies to your <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_DreadOverlord_Soulshield">Shield of Souls</LSTag>. Each <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="DREADOVERLORD_HARVESTED_SOUL">Captured Soul</LSTag> adds +[1] to your <LSTag Tooltip="ArmorClass">Armor Class</LSTag> until <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>. You may reap the dead in the heat of battle.
Reap the Dying

Wrench the very souls from the mortal husks of your weakened enemies and bind them to your <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_DreadOverlord_Soulshield">Shield of Souls</LSTag>. Executes enemies with less than 20% health. Each <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="DREADOVERLORD_HARVESTED_SOUL">Captured Soul</LSTag> adds +[1] to your <LSTag Tooltip="ArmorClass">Armor Class</LSTag> until <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>.

Harvesting souls beyond the current capacity of your soulshield overcharges it deflecting all spell and weapon projectiles for a short time. It will also result in an Empowered Soulshield granting additional effects to your spirit invocations.

Landing a killing blow unlocks Harvest Soul: Free Action for a turn, allowing you to harvest souls without using an action and a chance to restore a Warlock Spell Slot.
Invoke Spirit: Spook

Release a spirit from your soulshield to distract your enemies, allowing you to retreat to safety without spending any action or bonus action. This consumes the Captured Soul.

Empowered Soulshield: Your movement is doubled.

Release spirits from your soulshield to distract your enemies, allowing you to retreat to safety without spending any action or bonus action. Nearby enemies can be Frightened if they fail a Charisma Saving Throw. This consumes the Captured Souls.

Empowered Soulshield: Affected enemies are slowed and your movement is doubled.
Invoke Spirit: Apparition

You may command a spirit from your soulshield to come to the aid of an ally by expending a Reaction Point during your turn, adding +2 to their Armor Class for 3 turns. This consumes the Captured Soul.

Empowered Soulshield: Reduces all incoming damage by 1.

You may command spirits from your soulshield to come to the aid of an ally by expending a Reaction Point during your turn, adding +[1] to their Armor Class for 3 turns. This consumes the Captured Souls.

Empowered Soulshield: Reduces all incoming damage by [2].
Invoke Spirit: Phantasm

Will a ghostly phantasm from your soulshield to strike a target of your choosing, dealing [1] on a hit. This consumes the Captured Soul.

Empowered Soulshield: Doubles the damage of each Phantasm.

Will [2] ghostly phantasms from your soulshield to strike your foes, each dealing [1] on a hit. This consumes the Captured Souls.

Empowered Soulshield: Doubles the damage of each Phantasm.
Legendary Spirit Invocation: Phantasm
Will [2] ghostly phantasms from your soulshield to strike your foes, each dealing [1] on a hit.
Invoke Spirit: Haunt

Command angry spirits from your soulshield to haunt your enemies. The Captured Souls form into [1] shadow wraiths for [2] turns.

Empowered Soulshield: Shadows have Haste.

Command angry spirits from your soulshield to haunt your enemies. The Captured Souls form into [1] shadow wraiths for [2] turns. The wraiths can use Dark Currents and Darkness Cloak.

Empowered Soulshield: Shadows have Haste.
Invoke Spirit: Poltergeist

Release troublesome spirits from your soulshield to harass your enemies, moving objects and shoving creatures [1] away from you. Their mischief dazes enemies on a failed Charisma Saving Throw. This consumes the Captured Souls.

Empowered Soulshield: The poltergeists lash out in anger, dealing [2] or half that if targets succeed on their Charisma Saving Throw.

Release troublesome spirits from your soulshield to harass your enemies, moving objects and shoving creatures [1] away from you. Their mischief knocks enemies Prone on a failed Charisma Saving Throw. This consumes the Captured Souls.

Empowered Soulshield: The poltergeists lash out in anger, dealing [2] or half that if targets succeed on their Charisma Saving Throw.
Shroud de Aeternus Vitae

Wield a vampiric shroud that absorbs the vitality of nearby living enemies. Its dark tendrils inflict [1] to enemies and heal you for [2] per turn. The shroud persists until your next <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>. Affected enemies caught inside the shroud continually <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLEEDING">bleed</LSTag>.
Activating <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="DreadOverlord_DarkEmpathy">Dark Empathy</LSTag> extends the power of the shroud to your allies, sharing [1] of healing with them.
<LSTag Type="Image" Info="SoftWarning"/> The shroud has no effect on undead and constructs.
Summoner of the Damned: Skeletal Giant

Create a skeletal giant under your command. A massive frontline attacker, this <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="DreadOverlord_ImmuneToControlUndead">Greater Undead</LSTag> strikes with <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="DreadOverlord_GiantSlam_Passive">phenomenal power</LSTag>. Once per turn, the skeletal giant can slam its weapon into enemies in a <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_DreadOverlord_SkeletalGiant_Slam">Gargantuan Strike</LSTag>.
<LSTag Type="Image" Info="SoftWarning"/> The target must be a Large or Medium corpse.
Gargantuan Strike
Slam the massive weapon into enemies with unbridled force, creating a small shockwave centered on the target and knocking all creatures <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="PRONE">Prone</LSTag>.
Careful! Not even allies are safe from your terrible power!
Glaring Threat
<LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="TAUNTED">Goad</LSTag> enemies into attacking you.
Brutal Leap
Leap into enemies. Your sheer size knocks creatures <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="PRONE">Prone</LSTag>.
Summoner of the Damned: Skeletal Warlock

Bind into a corpse the spirit of a powerful warlock under your command. This <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="DreadOverlord_ImmuneToControlUndead">Greater Undead</LSTag> has access to <LSTag Type="Passive" Tooltip="DreadOverlord_UndeadPactMagic">Pact Magic</LSTag> from your patron, allowing it to cast powerful spells and recharge its <LSTag Tooltip="SpellSlot">Spell Slots</LSTag> after each <LSTag Tooltip="ShortRest">Short Rest</LSTag>.

The Skeletal Warlock can cast <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_BurstingSinew">Bursting Sinew</LSTag> and <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Projectile_DreadOverlord_RayOfSickness">Nell's Ray of Sickness</LSTag> at will. It can cast <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_FogCloud_2">Fog</LSTag>, <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_Blindness">Blindness</LSTag>, and <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_PhantasmalForce">Phantasmal Force</LSTag> as 2nd-level spells using its two Level 2 spell slots. It gains the ability to cast the spells <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_BestowCurse">Bestow Curse</LSTag> at class level 10 and <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_PhantasmalKiller">Phantasmal Killer</LSTag> at class level 11 once per <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>.

...The Book of the Dead. Bound in human skin and inked in the blood of murderers. This unholy book contains bizarre burial rites, funerary incantations, and demon resurrection passages. It was never meant for the eyes of the living. It was never meant for you. You recall ancient legends that tell that within the pages of this blasphemous book lies the secrets of eternal life beyond death. Words seemingly writhe across the pages of the book, becoming undecipherable the more you try to translate the text. The scrawls occasionally form coherent words, beckoning you to glean their secrets...
...Dread Overlord... ...aeternusvitae...
...Order of the Dracolich... ...Soul Harvest...
..the Greater Undead...
Forbidden Lore: Libor Mortis

[Whispers, barely audible at first, darken your mind becoming louder and more insistent. You feel the presence of your patron as the world dissolves around you save for a leather-bound book. A chill overtakes you as your eyes flit across the words on the cover - Libor Mortis. Its pages open revealing its secrets to you...]
[Whispers, barely audible at first, darken your mind before becoming eerily silent. This copy of the Libor Mortis is dormant, waiting for those who have yet to glimpse its profane secrets.]

[Whispers, barely audible at first, darken your mind becoming louder and more insistent. You feel a presence you do not recognize, powerful and... malevolent. The world begins to dissolve around you save for a leather-bound book. A chill overtakes you as your eyes flit across the words on the cover - Libor Mortis. Its pages reluctantly open...]

[Whispers, barely audible at first, darken your mind before becoming eerily silent. You note the words on the cover - Libor Mortis. What knowledge this mysterious tome possesses, it refuses to share with you.]
Forbidden Lore: The Undying Emperor

An ancient dracolich said to hail from a world beyond Toril. The Dread Overlord's many names include: Monolith of Terror, Lich King, Plague, Fear Incarnate, and Undying Emperor. His keep is known as the Dread Citadel or the Dragon Keep, and His cultists are collectively known as the Order of the Dracolich.

...the very air writhes in dread at His malevolent presence. His ruined form is flanked by two immense wings that spread behind Him like a great shadow and a tail tipped with wicked dark flame. His eyes - twin pinpricks of red light blazing in unholy power from within a draconic skull - bore down on us. The cultists shrank before the dracolich as the putrid stench of Death and Decay that surrounds Him like a malignant shroud overtook us. For the promise of knowledge and power, we willingly submitted to His terror and despair.

-- Sorakus the Hierarch of Disease

...the very air writhes in dread at His malevolent presence. His ruined form is flanked by two immense wings that spread behind him like a great shadow and a tail tipped with wicked dark flame. His eyes - twin pinpricks of red light blazing in unholy energy from within a draconic skull - bore down on us. The cultists shrank before the dracolich as the putrid stench of death and decay that surrounds him like a malignant shroud overtook us. For the promise of knowledge and power, we willingly submitted to His terror and despair.

-- Excerpt from the Libor Mortis
Forbidden Lore: Order of the Dracolich
The air around you grows chill and suddenly you feel your patron's presence. Your mind darkens as the world melts away save for a grotesque tome revealing its profane knowledge to you...

Corrupted by the Dread Overlord's cruelty, malice and will to dominate all life, the cultists of the Order of the Dracolich carry out His terror on Toril. In return for their service, the dracolich promised dominion over life and death itself with many cultists believing that with enough power you may overcome both. Wielding armies of undead, they devote their lives and unlives to the mastery over mortality. Their battlecry 'MORS PRINCIPIUM EST!' is in defiance over the very concept of finality.
Forbidden Lore: Soul Harvest
The air around you grows chill and suddenly you feel your patron's presence. Your mind darkens as the world melts away save for a grotesque tome revealing its profane knowledge to you...

...created by the evil lich Icarium the Black, the spell was one of the first he perfected during his many studies deep in the frontiers of Cormallen. He learned that by exerting his unholy will, he was able to bind the souls of his enemies into a swirling vortex of screaming spirits.

-- Excerpt from the Libor Mortis
Forbidden Lore: Shroud of Eternal Life
The air around you grows chill and suddenly you feel your patron's presence. Your mind darkens as the world melts away save for a grotesque tome revealing its profane knowledge to you...

A passage appears in the book before you, seemingly copied from a source outside the Book of the Dead, telling a very dry history of a legal squabble between a mage consortium and one of their apprentices. '...the experiments in unsanctioned magic became a point of contention between the High Mages and their best pupil. Prior to his expulsion from The Tower, the consortium expressed concern about the potential corrupting effects of his studies and sought...

...the writing on the page suddenly changes, seemingly mocking the documented history. Words and images dance on the page, depicting a betrayal from within, a plot by a devious necromancer in disguise, and the fall of The Tower. Then a war between the surviving high mages and an alliance of necromancers and deathknights led by a dracolich wielding the malignant Shroud de Aeternus Vitae. Faces and bodies desiccated by the dracolich's dark coils fill the pages of the unholy book. Screams from a long-forgotten battlefield surround you, reaching a deafening crescendo. You are paralyzed as dark tendrils slither out from very pages of the book...

...then screams emanating from the book quiet and the tendrils seeking you out dissipate. Words form telling a story of a dark ritual to bind the spirit of a powerful banshee within a living soul cage. Thin scrawls along the margins of the book appear, documenting the need for caution lest the necromancer finds themself possessed.
Forbidden Lore: The Greater Undead
The air around you grows chill and suddenly you feel your patron's presence. Your mind darkens as the world melts away save for a grotesque tome revealing its profane knowledge to you...

Some consider the raising of the Greater Undead as sacrilege. None can question the pure devastation a giant or a powerful warlock can cause while alive, but worse still when coupled with the unholy powers of necromancy. Warlocks who have failed to achieve lichdom or prevent their deaths have entered their names into the Libor Mortis in hopes that their damned souls will be returned into material plane in a semblance of unlife by a worthy necromancer. Only an evil warlock would willingly allow themselves to be raised in such a way. Luckily, the power necessary to raise such undead is within the means of only a few...

-- Excerpt from the Libor Mortis

...What follows are scribbles of incantations and pleas to ancient and long-forgotten gods of death and necromancy deities from planes and worlds from beyond Toril. Their names don't ring familiar to you - Vrall, Savoy, Enigma, Thy - but you sense unholy power behind them in the incantations.
Shield of Souls
Improved Shield of Souls
Greater Shield of Souls

A swirling vortex of spirits protects the necromancer from incoming attacks.

Has +[1] to Armor Class until Long Rest. [2] additional soul(s) may be bound to the soulshield.
Legendary Shield of Souls

A massive vortex of tortured souls rapidly swirl around screaming in agony, protecting this entity from incoming attacks.

Its soulshield provides +[1] to Armor Class and Immunity to[2] unless the damage dealt exceeds 20 hit points.

A swirling vortex of spirits protects this Greater Undead from incoming attacks.

Has +[1] to Armor Class until Long Rest.
Screaming Spirits
Souls of the dead scream in anguish around this creature before succumbing to its <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_DreadOverlord_Soulshield">soulshield</LSTag>.
Greater Shield of Souls

The souls of dead form a formidable shield of protection as they spiral around this creature wailing in agony.

Has +[1] to Armor Class until Long Rest.
Desecrated Corpse
This corpse has been defiled by a foul ritual.
Captured Soul

A soul of a recently slain creature cries in torment as it disappears into a soulshield.

Provides +[1] to Armor Class until Long Rest.
Captured Souls (Counter)

Souls of recently slain creatures cry in torment as they disappear into a soulshield.

Each captured soul provides +[1] to Armor Class until Long Rest. The soulshield may hold at the maximum up to [2] additional souls.

You have captured souls equal to the turns remaining.
Empowered Soulshield

A soul of a recently slain creature shrieks in anger as it disappears into the soulshield.

The spirit overcharges the shield, deflecting all spell and weapon projectiles for a short time.

All spirit invocations are empowered, providing additional effects.
Screaming Spirit
Screaming Spirits
Cries of terror fill the air as souls of the dead swirl around.
Ghostly Apparition
Ghostly Apparitions
A ghostly apparition has appeared near this creature protecting it from harm. Affected entity has +[1] to their <LSTag Tooltip="ArmorClass">Armor Class</LSTag>.
Ghostly apparitions surround this entity providing protection. Affected entity has +[1] to their <LSTag Tooltip="ArmorClass">Armor Class</LSTag>.
Necrotic Energies
This weapon blazes with your dracolich patron's fire, dealing extra[1].
This necromancer's weapon attacks burn with dark fire, dealing extra[1].
This undead's attacks blaze with dark fire, dealing extra[1].
Vampiric Shroud
Dark tendrils pour forth ominously from this creature's vampiric <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_DreadOverlord_ShroudDeAeternusVitae">Shroud de Aeternus Vitae</LSTag> in ravenous search of life.
Life Drained
This creature is being drained by a nearby <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_DreadOverlord_ShroudDeAeternusVitae">vampiric aura</LSTag>, receiving [1] per turn.
Feeding

Cuts and wounds close up on this creature's body as rivulets of vitality is stripped from nearby enemies by a <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_DreadOverlord_ShroudDeAeternusVitae">vampiric shroud</LSTag>.
Recharging
Your recent attempts to empathize with your allies has left you drained. Your <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_DreadOverlord_ShroudDeAeternusVitae">vampiric shroud</LSTag> is currently recharging.
Profane Possession
The soul of a <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_DreadOverlord_Animate_SkeletalMage">powerful warlock</LSTag> has been bound to this corpse to serve a dark design.
Unholy Vigor

Secret Societies of the Sword Coast: Exposed, Part II

The Cult of Ilyana
Rumors abound regarding the charismatic hero-witch Ilyana Miraquinal amassing a following as a main contender for ascension to goddess of adventurers. Though her feats are well-documented, it is known to few - including my illustrious contacts throughout Faerûn - that her right hand, Valkrana Miraquinal has ties to the underworld, necromancy, and the control of information as an infomonger and media mogul. Even fewer assert that Valkrana is responsible for the increase in skeletons across realmspace. Adventuring parties, beware!

The Order of the Dracolich
My sources claim that these Dread Cultists - as they are known to outsiders - serve an eldritch being from beyond our plane. Ludicrous! In fact, the answer to the mystery lies in the very name of the cult itself. The cult is bound to a powerful dracolich whose dark designs might imperil all of Toril yet.

The Path or OBW
Now that one is peculiar, for the actual name of the group is uncertain to me. I stumbled upon a letter - more likely a pamphlet - about necromancers following their deity, which I never heard of before. They called it The Revenant, but also a moon..? Are these adherents worshipping a celestial body, or an actual god? They seemingly have for ambition to rise as immortal undead. They serve their patron out of open selfishness, and strive for immortality, how original...

The letter displayed an OBW black wax seal, whatever this stands for. The meager evidence I have suggests they are not from Faerûn, possibly not even from Toril. It appears this group is trying to recruit new adepts, watch out for them. Best they remain where they are from, wherever that is.

Profane Blessing: Prelude to the Deathsong

You feel ancient necromancy humming within the blade as you grip the sword's handle. Then silence as you sense a rush of a familiar dread. No, not a feeling - someone is coming.

In shadows deep where whispers creep...

...a voice booms inside your head as the world darkens. It's your patron.

This sword a single note, a silent weep.
In secret realms, seek its kin,
And together, make a melody of sin.

With each stroke, the steel shall sing,
In battles fierce, dark powers you'll bring.
So go forth, the Deathsong to claim,
Then make profane symphony in my name!

And then... silence. Your patron has quested you to find the remaining brethrens of the weapon in your hands - ancestral relics brimming with untold necromantic potential.

[Profane Blessing: The Ebonblade grants Longsword and Greatsword proficiencies while wielded.]

Profane Blessing: Corrupted Armor

General Ketheric Thorm is dead. As you don his armor, you feel the rush of impending doom. You hear the sounds of battles fought and lost, the sorrows of oaths made and broken anew. The entire history of Thorm - from his rise and fall from grace and to his ultimate heartbreak - invades your mind. Then a chill born of the grave coils through the steel with the very breath of Death. The weight deepens - not mere steel now, but a vessel for souls unbound. The air thickens, the shadows lengthen, and something vast and unseen stirs. And then - a presence descends, and His voice resounds through your mind.

The tale of Thorm, the warrior's knell,
In shadowed lands where he fell.
A general's armor now you bear,
Exhort your enemies: "Take heed - beware!"

By dark design, let Fear take hold,
In iron clad, a story told.
Where you now tread, let Shadows fall,
And through your stride, let mortals crawl.

And then... the weight lifts - though the shadows remain. Your patron is pleased and His will now marches with you.

[Profane Blessing: Thorm's armor grants Medium and Heavy Armor proficiencies while worn. Souls of the dead are drawn to the armor granting you the unrestricted use of Shield of Souls - you will no longer lose Captured Souls while wearing any armor on your head, arms, and feet.]

Profane Blessing: Corrupted Grimoire

As the Necromancy of Thay snaps shut, you feel your patron's corruption seep from your being into the very pages of the book. The taint this dark magic leaves a lingering aftertaste in your mouth, acrid, rotten, and enticing. And then - a sensation. Someone was watching you. Your vision darkens, and from this void, a thundering voice wracks your mind.

Dark knowledge bound in cursed design,
The stolen tome of Thay, malign.
An oath betrayed, a master's crime,
Its power now shall cross through time.

Through blighted script and blood-stained page,
Let Shadow weave the binding cage.
Corrupt its heart with darkened art,
And seal the tome in Death's own chart.

And then... silence once again, and the world returns. For your initial corruption of the Necromancy of Thay, you have been granted profane powers by your patron. He has also quested you to decipher the grimoire's remaining secrets and fully corrupt it in His name. You intuit that the secrets to unlock its power can be found in Baldur's Gate.

[Profane Blessing: You know the profane powers Soul Magnet and Exhort the Risen.]

Profane Blessing: Corrupted Grimoire

You have fully deciphered, mastered, and corrupted the Necromancy of Thay in the Dread Overlord's name. In its corruption, the grimoire's deepest secrets regarding the nature of life and death are revealed to you and thus your patron. The taint of the dark magic you imbued the book leaves a familiar aftertaste in your mouth, even more acrid, rotten, and twisted than before. You expect what is coming, but are never fully prepared for it. Your vision begins to darken and then a voice that threatens to break your mind roars...

Thayan grimoire now seethed with blight,
A perfect work of ruined rite.
Its pages dark, defiled, complete,
A work no light could dare unseat.

Through Shadow's grasp and Death's command,
Its power sealed by binding hand.
Let none undo what has been done,
A tome beneath the shadow spun.

And then... silence once again and the world returns. Your complete corruption of the Necromancy of Thay has pleased your patron. His dominion now lingers upon the tome - and upon you.

[Profane Blessing: Your Pact Magic now includes a level 6 Shadow Spell Slot, which refreshes on Long Rest. You know the spells Curriculum of Strategy: Artistry of War, Dethrone, and Harm.]

Profane Blessing: Corrupted Necromancy

You have declared victory over the Mystic Carrion. As you seize the mummy lord's staff, a cold pulse ripples through the shaft - a thrumming echo of necromantic potential yet untapped. The lingering essence of the fallen lord coils within the relic, restless. Then - the air thickens, the staff seem to groan in your grasp. You are not alone. The presence descends - and with it, a voice like the grinding of stone upon stone crashes through your mind.

So hath decreed, the lord lay still,
Bound silent by a viler will.
His staff now seized by hands profane,
To bear the weight of Shadow's reign.

Through marrowed core and deathless art,
Let power through this relic start.
Awaken strength from crypt and bone,
Now wield the will of Death alone.

And then... silence once again and the world returns. The staff's dormant power stirs - and your patron's will deepens through your grasp.

[Profane Blessing: You gain Focused Necromancy and Empowered Curses while wielding the Staff of Cherished Necromancy.]

Profane Blessing: Cursed Wedding

Connor Vinderblad's pale form stands before you, his soul eternally bound to the wand you now hold. You hear laughter just out of the range of your hearing from a distance. No, not a distance - he is coming. Then silence - the familiar dread coils through you.

No living heart hath sworn so true,
As he who rose in shadowed hue.

...a voice booms inside your head as the world darkens. It's your patron.

By timeless bond now drawn and near,
To wed beyond all death and fear.

Let velvet oath now flood the air,
To love what none but death would dare.
Though flesh shall fade and time regret,
This bond remains - forever set.

In flesh now wan and gaze grown cold,
Let hand of life with death be bold.
By Fear Incarnate's ancient will,
So shall this binding now fulfill.

And then... silence. Your patron has joined you and Connor in profane matrimony.

[Profane Blessing: Connor Vinderblad is now your husband.
He retains some of his previous talents.]
Libor Mortis
An ancient tome filled with bizarre burial rites, funerary incantations, and demon resurrection passages.

[Whispers, barely audible at first, darken your mind becoming louder and more insistent. You feel the presence of your patron as the world dissolves around you save for a leather-bound book. A chill overtakes you as your eyes flit across the words on the cover - Libor Mortis. Its pages open revealing its secrets to you...]

[Rage - Mortal, feel the rage of the Libor Mortis. Years of possession in the hands of a lesser necromancer has angered this book. There is power resonating within this mysterious grimoire and it is offended by your desire to glean its profane secrets. Whispers, barely audible at first, rise to a deafening clamor. It does not like you.]

[As you hold the mysterious grimoire, a feeling of anger washes over you emanating from the book. Years of possession in the hands of a lesser necromancer have filled this book with malice. Then - as quickly as it appeared - the feeling dissipates as if the book was mollified by your touch. Whispers, barely audible at first, begin to darken your mind becoming louder and more insistent. You feel the presence of your patron as the world dissolves around you save for a leather-bound book. A chill overtakes you as your eyes flit across the words on the cover - Libor Mortis. Its pages open calmly revealing its secrets to you...]

Libor Mortis: Scientia Est Potentia

...The Book of the Dead. Bound in human skin and inked in the blood of murderers. It was never meant for the eyes of the living. It was never meant for you. You recall ancient legends that tell that within the pages of this blasphemous book lies the secrets of eternal life beyond death. Words seemingly writhe across the pages of the Libor Mortis, becoming undecipherable the more you try to translate the text. The scrawls occasionally form coherent words, beckoning you to glean their secrets...

...suddenly, a twisted phrase is blasted into your mind with the terrible might of the Undying Emperor. You glimpse pages and upon pages of the Libor Mortis - now countless and unbound by its physical form. The sum total of forbidden knowledge it once contained is compressed into a single searing burst of revelation - 'SCIENTIA EST POTENTIA!' 'Knowledge is power' and it is yours for the taking. Then the book snaps shut, concealing its secrets once more.

You are appointed by your patron to nurture your dark potential to pursue greater heights in your necromancy, and to search the lands for the Covenants of the Profane.

[Libor Mortis: You have gained Forbidden Knowledge. Add +1 to Wisdom Saving Throws and Ability Checks. You now know the necromancy cantrip Bursting Sinew.]

Libor Mortis: Mors Principium Est

...The Book of the Dead once more. The desiccated leather that covers the macabre tome drips with the blood of the wicked. The unholy writ opens, revealing names of those pactbound to the Dread Overlord who have failed to achieve lichdom or prevent their demise. Contained within are sacrilegious rituals to wake these free-willed Greater Undead from their eternal slumber, granting their damned souls passage to the world of the living in a semblance of unlife. The text begins to bleed, covering the pages of the book...

...suddenly, the crimson writing forms into accursed words, assaulting your mind with visions of iniquitous lives beyond reckoning. Resigned to the silent halls of death, the pallid retinue lingers beyond the veil awaiting your summons. The innumerable caravan shall come and 'MORS PRINCIPIUM EST!' shall be their battlecry. 'Death is only the beginning.' The red ichor staining the Libor Mortis begin to fade, leaving featureless pages. Then the book snaps shut, concealing its secrets once more.

Your patron commends you in your studiousness and has rewarded you accordingly.

[Libor Mortis: You have gained Forbidden Judgment. Add +1 to Intelligence Saving Throws and Ability Checks.]

Libor Mortis: Aeternus Vitae

...where once scrawls, an unfathomable darkness has subsumed the pages of the Book of the Dead. Words and images seemingly dance within the void, first imperceptible, then a rush of history assails your senses. A betrayal from within, a necromancer's plot, and images appear of an arcane tower toppled with but a single dark rose rising from its rubble. It is the history of your cult - the founding of the Order of the Dracolich...

...suddenly, you begin to hear screams from long-forgotten battlefields, reaching a deafening crescendo. Visions fill your mind of a war between mighty mages against an endless horde of undead led by a dragonborn wielding a malignant shroud of darkness. Faces and bodies desiccated by the shroud's dark coils fill the pages of the unholy tome threatening to ensnare you, and begin to dissolve into a single phrase - 'AETERNUS VITAE.' 'Eternal life' and now a weapon yours to wield. The screams emanating from the Libor Mortis quiet and the shadows dissipate. The book snaps shut, concealing its secrets once more.

Your devotion to the dark arts has not gone unnoticed.

[Libor Mortis: You have gained Forbidden Magnetism.
Add +1 to Charisma Saving Throws and Ability Checks.]
High Mages of the Tower v. Apprentice Azardon
A legal history of an ancient trial involving a mage consortium and an apprentice accused of practicing necromancy.

[What follows is an excerpt from a very dry history of a legal squabble between a mage consortium and one of their apprentices.]

The experiments in unsanctioned magic became a point of contention between the High Mages and their best pupil. The consortium expressed concern about the potential corrupting effects of his studies and sought to sanction what they believed to be profane arts. The apprentice was accused by the High Mages of practicing necromancy in direct contravention of the tenets of their Tower Magic. The High Mage Eldan of Ander defended his pupil, who dismissed such talk to be a product of paranoid worry. [...]

[The case concludes with the successful conviction and expulsion of the necromancer from the Tower's ranks.]
Bloody Report
Covered in blood, this dispatch is nigh unreadable save for a few words and a familiar symbol.

[A brief dispatch intercepted by the Emerald Grove from cultists working for an unknown organization. Despite making most of the document unreadable, you recognize a few words and a familiar symbol through the splotches of blood - that of the Dread Citadel.]

...arran band... the weapon... ...lost contact with team... ...hosen of Bha...
Good Tales for Well-Behaved Children
A storybook filled with tales that promote education and good behavior in children.

[A chapter from a children's storybook titled The Dragonmage Azardon.]

Azardon, under the personal tutelage of the High Mages, quickly became one of the most skilled users that ever attempted to wield the might of the special brand of magic the Tower possessed. In return for their guidance, the Dragonmage became the Tower's fiercest champion and enforcer of its rule. Being well-versed in dragonlore, the High Mages know that dragonkind's potential in magic is limitless and so taught Azardon everything they knew from basic cantrips to long-held secrets of the Tower.

[...]

[The story continues, emphasizing the importance of education and following authority.]
Battle Manual of the Dread Citadel, Part X
An ancient book on battle tactics using necromancy and the dark arts as practiced by a cult called the Order of the Dracolich.

[An excerpt from a correspondence titled Claws and Their Uses by the apprentice Azardon of the Tower, as originally sent to the High Mage Eldan of Ander. You recognized the name - Azardon of the Tower - was but a mortal guise, crafted to conceal the true and abyssal form of the Dread Overlord himself.]

The most versatile of all the minion types in terms of use, crawling claws can drag corpses, act as cannon fodder, and be used as ambulatory foci of dark magic. From the beginning of a mage's life to their peak of strength and power, these minions are a valuable and important addition to their undead menagerie.

Though objectively weaker than other summoned undead, claws can overwhelm even the most resilient of foes with their numbers. Another use for these crawling claws are as foci in spells such as Valkrana's Corpse Grenade, Vrall's Putrefaction, and Enigma's Armor of Bones.

[...]
War of the Dark Rose and Rise of the Order of the Dracolich
A historical account of the war between the High Mages of the Tower and the deathmages of the Dark Rose.

[What follows is a recounting the conflict between a mage consortium called The Tower and a rebellion led by necromancers and death-knights of the Dark Rose.]

The Tower was in reality in a period of crisis as a union of necromancers and death-knights calling themselves The Dark Rose formed challenging the High Mages' dominion over the region. The battlemages of the Tower were increasingly being tested, not only by the strength of their foes, but the seemingly endless supply of them. The necromancers are never in short supply of undead minions they raise against the Tower's champions. Entire villages would be massacred to swell the Dark Rose's ranks.

[...]

And on that six-hundred and first day since the start of the siege, the Tower fell, betrayed from within. Thus, begin two centuries of rule by the Dark Rose.

[...]

[The book continues with the Dark Rose's untimely collapse after a prolonged power struggle that decimated its ranks. Rising from the ashes of the Dark Rose was a vicious cult called the Order of the Dracolich - led by a dracolich king simply called the Dread Overlord.]
Battered Journal
A journal of Ilyn Toth, looking worse for wear.

18 Nightal, 1371 DR

A cultist bearing a symbol of the Dread Citadel came to the village last night and into my care. According to my apprentice, it appears that she was involved in a tussle with Dark Justiciars near Reithwin and sustained life-threatening injuries. Unfortunately for her, the deep wounds has been 'resistant' to my healing.

[A few entries later, an excited scrawl regarding the condition of the cultist.]

My new patient is dead finally and she has on her person another Book of the Dead - one of the most prized posessions of the Order of the Dracolich! Those necromancers do not lightly part with their unholy book. I must take care to conceal it lest their deathmages come after me in their wrath.

I can feel the dark magic seeping from the book, a worthy twin to the one I currently possess. What profane knowledge will I glean from it? I cannot wait.
Poorly Encrypted Dispatch
A urgent dispatch to the Paladins of Tyr, encrypted with a simple cipher.

[Whoever encrypted this dispatch was in a hurry as it took no time at all to decipher.]

Anders,

You were right about the Dread cultists tracking the Sharrans, though it seems both parties met their untimely end at Baldur's Gate at the hands of an unknown foe. As far as we know, none survived. We do not yet know what designs either the Order of the Dracolich or the Sharran cult might have in the city and we don't care to know. No more distractions. Focus on the mission the Dark Lady entrusted you. Find the renegade tiefling.
Order of the Dracolich: Scientia Est Potentia, Part One
A collection of essays on the pursuit of knowledge. Etched on the cover with what seems to be blood is a draconic skull, winged and flying above a keep.

[What follows is an excerpt from a speech titled Epistemology of Power: Understanding Knowledge as delivered by the Deathmage Azardon to the graduating initiates of the Dark Rose in 2001 NR. The Hierarchs of Disease of your order taught you that the Dark Rose was an alliance of necromancers and deathknights that defeated the High Mages of the Tower in their stead a thousand years ago. From this alliance, the Order of the Dracolich was forged, after a prolonged power struggle that decimated the Dark Rose's ranks. You recognize the name of this deathmage and it dawns on you - the celebrated Deathmage Azardon was but a mortal guise, crafted to conceal the true and abyssal form of the Dread Overlord himself.]

Within the higher arcana, the maxim Scientia Est Potentia - Knowledge is Power - is no idle phrase. It is law. Immutable. Binding. Those who would rise within this Order - or beyond it - must grasp this at the root. To know is to command. To command is to conquer.

In necromantic practice, knowledge is not gathered - it is taken. Ripped from the unseen. Wrested from the dead. No adept who fears to trespass beyond mortal boundaries shall master it. The veil is no shield - it is a gate. And it opens for those who possess the will to force it so.

Understand this: the truths you seek do not rest in your tomes, nor in the whispers of lesser mentors. They lie beyond - in the hollows of the dead, in the marrow of forgotten kings. Only through ritual, through relentless communion with forces cast beyond life, may such knowledge be claimed.

In so doing, you do not merely learn - you are transformed. Dominion over death is not granted. It is forged. Those who hesitate, who flinch from the communion of bone and spirit, shall serve as dust beneath the will of those who do not.

[...]

Thus is Scientia Est Potentia made manifest: not as idle pursuit, but as a blade. A yoke. A path that none who begin it may set aside. You will seek. You will claim. You will be remade - or you will fall. There is no other truth in this plane or beyond it.
Initiate's Letter
A letter from a daughter to her mother.

Mama,

Greetings from the Dread Citadel! I don't know what I was expecting, but it's a lot cozier than I thought even for new initiates such as I myself. I know it's been a while since I left Baldur's Gate, and I wanted to take the opportunity to write to you and let you know how much I miss everyone. They're planning to send us off to train somewhere uncivilized, so I will not be writing the next a four tendays, but I will try once we return from the wilderness. But please continue to write as letters will still be delivered to the initiates' accomodations at the keep.

I'm afraid Mama, sometimes I think I made a mistake, but then I think of Papa and it makes my resolve even stronger. The Undying Emperor is promising us so much power, Mama. Power to bring him back so we can be a family again. I will learn as much as I can... I miss him so much...

Love,
Itansha, Initiate of the Dark Arts
Order of the Dracolich
Regretful Letter
A letter from a new recruit with the Order of the Dracolich.

Demosthenes,

I fucking hate it here. The walls themselves smell of corpses, I don't know how I'm the only one noticing it. The other initiates don't seem to mind or if they do mind, act like they don't smell it themselves. I am also terrified of laying my eyes on the emperor, Demos. They say there's gonna be a ritual where we chant and worship the dragon in a large cavern below the citadel, but all I know is I'm gonna shit myself if that happens! I don't want no power over life and death, I just want a job. I can't get out of this, I am so scared.

- Loki

[The letter ends with a crude drawing of the initiate prostrate before a skeletal dragon and projectile defecating on the other end.]
Unsent Dispatch
An encrypted message bearing the symbol of the Dread Citadel.

[The missive below was encrypted with a script known only to the deathmages of the Order of the Dracolich. Try as you might, you cannot decipher the text. The message ends with a familiar symbol of the Dread Citadel, a draconic skull, winged and above a black keep.]
Meditations on Death
A contemplation written in a shaky hand.

Thanatopsis by William Cullen Bryant

To him who in the love of Nature holds
Communion with her visible forms, she speaks
A various language; for his gayer hours
She has a voice of gladness, and a smile
And eloquence of beauty, and she glides
Into his darker musings, with a mild
And healing sympathy, that steals away
Their sharpness, ere he is aware. When thoughts
Of the last bitter hour come like a blight
Over thy spirit, and sad images
Of the stern agony, and shroud, and pall,
And breathless darkness, and the narrow house,
Make thee to shudder, and grow sick at heart; -
Go forth, under the open sky, and list
To Nature's teachings, while from all around -
Earth and her waters, and the depths of air -
Comes a still voice -

[...]

So live, that when thy summons comes to join
The innumerable caravan, which moves
To that mysterious realm, where each shall take
His chamber in the silent halls of death,
Thou go not, like the quarry-slave at night,
Scourged to his dungeon, but, sustained and soothed
By an unfaltering trust, approach thy grave,
Like one who wraps the drapery of his couch
About him, and lies down to pleasant dreams.
Executed Dread Cultist
Damaged Armor of the Soulshepherd
An armor of the soulshepherd of the Dread Citadel. Save for the dents and dried blood staining the metal, it's still serviceable. Souls of the dead are strangely drawn to it.
Armor of the Soulshepherd
A recently reforged armor, once worn by the deathmages of the Dread Citadel. Souls of the dead are strangely drawn to it.
Citadel Metalworks
You are considered <LSTag Tooltip="ArmourProficiency">Proficient</LSTag> with this armor while wearing it.
Dossier on the Dread Citadel
A compilation of information on the activities of the Dread cultists of the Order of the Dracolich.

Nine-Fingers,

Compiled for your convenience are various pieces of information, both confirmed and unsubstantiated, on the designs of the Order of the Dracolich. Some of these include historical information and urban legends about what goes on in the Dragon Keep.

We can confirm that a necromancer or a group of necromancers run the show at the very top, but we cannot verify the existence of an undead dragon that persists in these tales. These cultists could very well be sharing a mass delusion, but our experience with the Cult of the Dragon is telling us to pay attention. If these cultists claim to be serving a dracolich, they might very well be.

- Bursar Uktar

P.S. There's new information on the small group of Dread cultists we've been tracking from Baldur's Gate - we don't know as of yet how many survived, but they've resurfaced near the Nautiloid crash and may or may not have joined forces with either Sharrans, Githyankis, or rogue Absolute cultists.

All we know so far is that they seemed to have shed any semblance of secrecy and are currently making a huge mess of things east of Moonhaven. Our reports indicate they have clashed with Absolute forces attacking a druid enclave.

I'll update you as soon as I can.
Unreadable Grimoire
A book of spells emblazoned with a symbol of a draconic skull, winged and above a black keep - the Order of the Dracolich.

[This small tome was encrypted with a simple script taught to the new recruits of the Order of the Dracolich. Deciphering the text, you realize quickly that this is not a book of spells, but rather a book of initiate's prayers.]

Monolith of Terror,
Beneath His fearsome reign,
The land stained
In anguish and pain.

Avatar of Despair,
Beneath His darkness profound,
No solace is found
In shadows bound.

Fear Incarnate,
Beneath His relentless blight,
Dark fire ignite
In endless night.

Dread Overlord,
Beneath His dark decay,
The dead pray
In malevolence's sway.
Totem of the Necromancer

Profane Blessing: Citadel Arcana

The ancient necromancy within this Totem of the Necromancer surges through you. Screams - of the long dead and of those yet to die - echo all around. Then silence - and dread, thick as the grave, descends. No, not dread - a presence approaches.

Seek the altars where spirits embark,

...the air turns cold, the shadows deepen - and a voice, vast and unbidden, crashes through your mind. It is your patron.

In cellars deep and Underdark.
By withered bones, unlock your might
Where Death must walk 'neath Shadowed night.

Totems of bones, wrought and profane,
Lores of yore in whispers remain.
Each altar found, a new pact laid,
Between warlock and Endless Shade.

And then... silence once again, and the world returns. Your patron has set you upon this path - each totem you corrupt deepens His dominion, and draws you further into His shadow. Find these altars of bone between here and Baldur's Gate.

[Profane Blessing: You gain an additional +1 to Arcana and +1 to History skill checks.]

[Before you is a grisly arrangement of bones, knitted together in a macabre sculpture. Skulls of long dead scribes form the base of the grotesque display. Painted in dried blood on one of the skulls is your cult's familiar symbol - a draconic skull, winged and above a black keep - of the Order of the Dracolich.]

[You approach the bone altar with a mix of reverence and fear. With the Forbidden Lore taught to you by the Hierarchs of Disease of your order, you recall altars of bone erected by necromancers of antiquity in places brimming with necromantic potential. You kneel before the altar and mutter a simple prayer, commiting the morbid shrine in the name of the Dread Overlord.]

[As you reach out to touch the weathered bone of the altar, you feel a pulse - a faint of echo of power still resonating through the bones as if they remembered the ghastly rituals performed upon them long ago...]
Profane Blessing: Citadel Arcana

Your patron is pleased with your discovery and commitment of one of His ancient bone totems and has rewarded you with additional knowledge. Add +1 to any roll made with either <LSTag Tooltip="Arcana">Arcana</LSTag> or <LSTag Tooltip="History">History</LSTag>.

Profane Blessing: Armor of Souls

Ancient necromancy in the altar of bones burns through you, hotter than the scorching heat from the lava below. Reality buckles - and from the blaze of dark flame, His voice rises, drowning all else in its inferno.

Spirits lost in unending hate,
Each soul is sealed within the plate.
In Loss's Forge, their spirits burn,
So that their agony you'll learn.

An armored tomb of captured spite,
To fill you with abyssal might.
Now wear this chorus of despair,
And damn this world to Death's dark lair.

And then... silence once again and the world returns. It was your patron, and He is pleased.

Profane Blessing: Thayan Alchemy

The rot in that altar of bones doesn't coil. It writhes. A bitter, chemical poison that scours the air, branding your tongue and setting your lungs alight. The stench of putrid reagents and scorched blood chokes the silence. And then a voice from the void resounds.

Dark arts of Thay, with flask and blight,
And turn all living things to Night.
Their feeble lore, once thought so pure,
Now yields before a darker cure.

Now take this plague of perfect dread,
And let Death's lethal plague be spread.
Unleash Fear's wrath in bone and rust,
And grind their hollow world to dust.

And then... silence once again and the world returns. It was your patron, and He is pleased. Thay's alchemical secrets are now yours.

Profane Blessing: Myconid Necromancy

The necromancy in this mossy altar pours through you. A cloying rot fills your lungs, the scent of decay thick upon the air. No, not a feeling - a presence approaches.

Beneath earth where mycelium winds,
A lore of rot the Shadow binds.
Through root and spore, through creeping Blight,
The ancient craft is turned to Night.

Let hidden rites in fungus grown,
Be claimed as Death's dominion shown.
Through altar bound, corrupted lore,
Now serves Doom's will forevermore.

And then... silence once again and the world returns. Through root and rot, His shadow spreads. It was your patron, and He is pleased.

Profane Blessing: Might of the Lich King

...a cold beyond life seeps into your marrow, entwining thought and flesh alike. Slivers of the ancient necromancy still resonating from within the unholy shrine calls out to you, before becoming a torrent of darkness that overwhelms the senses. Where shadowed power once enthralls.
A power forged in Endless Night,

In taloned grasp, a reaper wrought,
From bones and breath where life is naught.
By Fear Incarnate's dread command,
By Wrath and Shadow on the land.

On Soul Harvest

...created by the evil lich Icarium the Black, the spell was one of the first he perfected during his many studies deep in the frontiers of Cormallen. He learned that by exerting his unholy will, he was able to bind the souls of his enemies into a swirling vortex of screaming spirits called a Shield of Souls.

[...]

[The text continues, reminding the reader that the wearing of any armor, should it be light or heavy armor, encumbers the necromancer preventing them from retaining control of their Captured Souls.]

[As you unseal the Libor Mortis, the air thickens and the world falls away until only the blighted tome remains before you. A cold weight settles over your flesh. This is no mere sensation - it is will. The presence of your patron coils through your mind, His voice not heard but known: ascend in power and seek the Covenants of the Profane, for in them truths forbidden and powers unholy await. Red ichor mars the pages, revealing more secrets...]

On Greater Undead

Some consider the raising of the Greater Undead as sacrilege. None can question the pure devastation a giant or a powerful warlock can cause while alive, but worse still when coupled with the unholy powers of necromancy. Warlocks who have failed to achieve lichdom or prevent their deaths have entered their names into the Libor Mortis in hopes that their damned souls will be returned into the material plane in a semblance of unlife by a worthy necromancer. Only an evil warlock would willingly allow themselves to be raised in such a way. Luckily, the power necessary to raise such undead is within the means of only a few...

[...What follows are scribbles of incantations and pleas to ancient and long-forgotten gods of death and necromancy deities from planes and worlds from beyond Toril. Their names don't ring familiar to you - Vrall, Savoy, Enigma, Thy - but you sense unholy power behind them in the incantations.]

Libor Mortis: Covenants of the Profane

Your research into the Totems of the Necromancer and entrance into new covenants with your patron has yielded additional insights into the powers and secrets the Libor Mortis holds.

Libor Mortis: Covenants of the Profane

...no other script mars the pages of the Libor Mortis - only a shadowed sigil depicting the symbol of the Order of the Dracolich. What once was inked in ichor drawn from the freshly butchered now thrums with a sinister pulse. No rites of peace linger here - only the weight of bound pacts. As your gaze lingers, the sigil writhes - melting, reforming, pulling you inward. Visions seize your mind: shades swirling in endless void, marrowed remains twisting in unseen bindings, and the blood of the dead congealing into formless rites. The Covenant is complete. Then - the air shudders. A voice, vast as the grave, tears through your thoughts.

With fell pacts sealed, and Shadow calls,
Through bound domains, the curtain falls.
In spirits' wails, in bones' embrace,
In bloodied paths, now find your place.

By pact of three, the rite is done,
The keys to Doom's dominion won.
Through page and will and Endless Shade,
Your fate beneath Death's grasp is laid.

Then the Libor Mortis snaps shut - its secrets claimed, its will now writ upon your soul.

[Libor Mortis: You have found all the Covenants of the Profane, unlocking the spells Vrall's Putrefaction, Enigma's Armor of Bones, and Savoy's Embrace of Death.]
Battle Manual of the Dread Citadel, Part VIII

An ancient book on battle tactics using necromancy and the dark arts as practiced by a cult called the Order of the Dracolich. The book is filled with various slips of paper marking specific chapters.

[An excerpt from a necromantic study titled Treatise on the Practical Applications of Spirits by Sorakus the Zealot, Hierarch of Disease of the Order of the Dracolich. The page is marked with scribbles of unreadable notes on the margins.]

...Not since the lich Icarium the Black's invention of the spell Soul Harvest has the realm of necromancy witnessed such a seismic shift in the accessibility of spirit invocation. Libor Mortis: Opening the Book

...The Book of the Dead. Bound in human skin and inked in the blood of murderers. It was never meant for the eyes of the living. It was never meant for you. Words seemingly writhe across the pages of the book, becoming undecipherable the more you try to translate the text. The scrawls occasionally form coherent words, beckoning you to glean their secrets...

Then the book snaps shut, concealing its secrets from you.

[Libor Mortis: You have been castigated by a fell power from daring to read what is not yours.]

Profane Intervention: Totems of the Necromancer

From Eltugard to Baldur's Gate, altars of bone have been defiled in the name of the Dread Overlord. By your dark will, the potent necromancy and forbidden knowledge held within these macabre shrines have been subsumed and corrupted. While there are many more of these unholy constructs throughout the Sword Coast and all over Faerun, what you have found and collected in your journey have pleased your patron.

A hint of a smile appears on your lips as a familiar dread overcomes you. Now you welcome the fear, now you welcome the darkness. Then a roar that would shatter mountains invades your mind as the world plunges into the void. He approaches...

In Underdark and temples deep,
Through shadowed lands and Moonlight's Keep,
Each grim construct, defiled by hate,
Now serve a vile and darkened fate.

From withered shrines, forbidden lore,
Powers profane and new oaths swore.
Fell spirits, bound to ancient bone,
All kneel before the Shadow's throne.

With blighted rot and soul-bound steel,
Claimed and tainted in corrupt seal.
Bloodied craft and unholy rite,
Unleashed the Wrath of Endless Night.

Arise, Chosen of Fear and Dread,
And reign among the listless dead.
Let this new age of unlife start,
To reap the world in Death's dark art.

And then... silence once again, and the world returns. You have been named
the Chosen of the Dread Overlord and have been gifted
the fearsome powers of the Corrupted Totems of the Necromancer.

Reinforcements from the Dread Citadel

Peril - your only constant companion since your journey began has been peril. From the burning wastes of Avernus and the sunless depths of the Underdark, to the star-mad expanse of the Astral Sea and the suffocating silence of the Shadowfell, you have tread realms of which only a few mortals could dream.

Every forbidden secrets wrested from the lesser, every profane power seized from the forgotten, every foe of the Dread Citadel vanquished, all have forged you into the only weapon that can face the coming trial.

And now, that moment is upon you. With what allies you have gathered by your side, you face not merely a battle for the future of Faerun, but a desperate war for all existence. 'The planes thus quake, and the gods shudder'.

In the final hour, from the threshold of oblivion, a plea for profane intervention shall be answered by the Undying Emperor. His reply is not the the whisper of crypts, but a cataclysm - the sky will tear open, unleashing the terrible wrath of the Dread Citadel. The Dread Overlord will join you in this fight, and with Him comes an army of the undead.

[You now know the spell Profane Intervention: Aspect of the Dread Overlord, if you have not already. Additional undead will join your patron in battle.]

Horn of the Dread Citadel
An elegant horn made from fine ivory and inlaid with gold. It bears the standard of the Order of the Dracolich - a draconic skull, winged and flying above a black keep.

Sound the horn to command all those fighting under the banner of the Order of the Dracolich to Attack At-Will.

For the duration of combat, all your summons will fight of their own accord without further instructions if they are not already.

Regain control of your rampaging army by sounding the horn once more.

Entities must be not be Deafened.
Horn of the Dread Citadel: Attack At-Will

Summoner of the Damned: Horn of the Dread Citadel

As your undead army grows, so too must your command. Sound the Horn of the Dread Citadel in the heat of battle to command those fighting under the banner of the Order of the Dracolich to unleash their wrath against your enemies at-will.

Visage of the Undying Emperor

The construction of this greathelm evokes the very symbol of the Dread Citadel: a visage of death flanked by two immense wings. You wonder how it found its way to the House of Hope's fiercely guarded vaults.

[Technical: Shadow Army Check]
Profane Power: Thy's Gloomsworn

Using the Libor Mortis, raise shadow beings from the mortal husks of your fallen enemies.

These Gloomsworn Undead retain some of their abilities from their previous lives and will fight under the banner of the Order of the Dracolich.

Traveling between regions will return the gloomsworn to their mortal husks and their corpses will be delivered to your inventory by your grimoire.

However, not all corpses will survive the trip and will disintegrate upon being placed on the ground.
Gloomsworn Undead

Shadow beings eternally bound to a powerful necromancer through the use of a foul ritual and will fight for their summoner until all that is left of them are forgotten memories.

They have access to Pact Magic from a fell power, empowering their abilities and spells without the need of spell slots or class resources.

Equip a shortbow.

Gloomsworn Weapons
Choose a weapon to wield. You have the choice between a shortbow, scimitar, flail, or a quarterstaff.
Profane Power: Recall Gloomsworn

Using the legendary Libor Mortis, recall Gloomsworn Undead and store them inside the unbound depths of your grimoire.

Traveling between regions will empty your Libor Mortis of the gloomsworn, returning their damned souls to their mortal husks.

Their corpses will be delivered to your inventory by your grimoire - however, not all corpses will survive the trip and will disintegrate upon being placed on the ground.
Profane Power: Summon Gloomsworn Army

From the very pages of the Libor Mortis, summon your Gloomsworn Undead army back into the Material Plane.

Traveling between regions will empty your Libor Mortis of the gloomsworn, returning their damned souls to their mortal husks.

Their corpses will be delivered to your inventory by your grimoire - however, not all corpses will survive the trip and will disintegrate upon being placed on the ground.
[Technical: Night of the Living Dead Check]

Profane Power: Thy's Gloomsworn

Any Gloomsworn Undead you might had recently or stored have returned to their mortal husks as you traverse to a different region. As such, the Libor Mortis has delivered their bodies to you to be desecrated once more.

[Profane Power: Corpses of your Gloomsworn Undead - including those stored in the Libor Mortis - have been transferred to your inventory. Most corpses will persist, however some are too fragile to make the trip and will disintegrate upon being moved from your inventory.]
Soul Tether
This copy of the Libor Mortis is eternally bound to the Dread cultist who first unlocked its secrets. Or whomever wrested it from the unlucky cultist's corpse.
